qas.question: The Indus Valley Civilization was the first to have traces of what?
What proportional size were the bricks that the civilization used?
What characteristic determined the proportions of the bricks?
What was the name of the ruler that they created?
How long were the units in inches of the Mohenjo-daro ruler?

context: Mathematics: The earliest traces of <a0_0>mathematical knowledge<a0_0/> in the Indian subcontinent appear with the Indus Valley Civilization (c. 4th millennium BC ~ c. 3rd millennium BC). The people of this civilization made bricks whose dimensions were in the proportion <a1_0>4:2:1<a1_0/>, considered favorable for the <a2_0>stability<a2_0/> of a brick structure. They also tried to standardize measurement of length to a high degree of accuracy. They designed a ruler—<a3_0>the Mohenjo-daro ruler<a3_0/>—whose unit of length (approximately <a4_0>1.32 inches<a4_0/> or 3.4 centimetres) was divided into ten equal parts. Bricks manufactured in ancient Mohenjo-daro often had dimensions that were integral multiples of this unit of length.
